conclusion: Set up the electrodynamic equations
Total circuit resistance is R_tot = R + r
Motional e.m.f. of the rod is E = BLv
Induced current is I = BLv / (R + r)
Magnetic braking force is F_B = B^2L^2v / (R + r)
Component of gravity pulling the rod down the slope is F_g = mg sin(theta)
Define constants k = B^2L^2 / (R + r) and tau = m / k = m(R + r) / B^2L^2
Solve the equation of motion using Newton's second law
Equation of motion is m dv/dt = mg sin(theta) - kv
Solution to the ODE is v(t) = v_max(1 - e^(-t/tau)), v_max = mg sin(theta) / k
Displacement as a function of time
Distance slid after time t is x(t) = v_max[t - tau(1 - e^(-t/tau))]
Introduce dimension-less quantity q = x / (v_max tau) = y - 1 + e^(-y), y = t/tau
Invert x(t) to obtain t(x)
Transcendental relation q = y - 1 + e^(-y) solved with Lambert-W function: t = tau[q + 1 + W(-e^(-(q+1)))]
Write t in the given symbols
v_max tau = m^2g sin(theta) / k^2 = m^2g sin(theta)(R + r)^2 / B^4L^4
q = k^2x / (m^2g sin(theta)) = B^4L^4x / (m^2g sin(theta)(R + r)^2)
Required time is t = m(R + r) / B^2L^2 [1 + B^4L^4x / (m^2g sin(theta)(R + r)^2) + W(-exp(-1 - B^4L^4x / (m^2g sin(theta)(R + r)^2)))]
Practical note on Lambert-W function
